questions.content: Transylvania was predominantly Romanian in terms of demographics in 1918.
questions.explanation: The devil in the details is the meaning of 'predominantly'. Romanians were the majority, but probably not an absolute one.

questions.content: Many of the negative traits in modern Romanian society stem from the so-called Phanariot period.
questions.explanation: The so-called Phanariots are responsible for the initial wave of modernisation and for bringing Moldavia and Wallachia closer together, paving the way for the future union. They have a poor reputation as 'foreigners'.

questions.content: Ceaușescu's early contributions to the population's welfare were irrefutable.
questions.explanation: This question is completely out of my area of expertise.

questions.content: Michael the Brave's actions in 1600, which unified Wallachia, Transylvania, and Moldavia under his rule, were motivated by a national goal to unite all Romanians.
questions.explanation: There are numerous letters and memoirs written by Michael, some by his own hand. Not once did he refer to such a 'national goal'.

questions.content: After Emperor Aurelian's withdrawal from Dacia, continuity in population, language and culture persisted in the region.
questions.explanation: This is straightforward: there is no such thing as long-term continuity in population, language, or culture throughout history.

questions.content: The Romanian lands were integrated, to varying degrees and for varying periods of time, into the Ottoman Empire.
questions.explanation: Some might argue that the tributary states were not part of the Ottoman Empire (they were).

questions.content: The anti-Ottoman resistance of the Romanian countries defended Western Europe.
questions.explanation: The so-called resistance was sporadic at best, and the main route to Buda and Vienna did not pass through Wallachia or Transylvania.

questions.content: Vlad Țepeș' cruelty denotes pathological behavior.
questions.explanation: Probably not all historians would agree with me on this point. But I am ready to stand by it.

questions.content: The Treaty of Trianon in 1920 was a historical injustice to the Hungarian population.
questions.explanation: It certainly felt like that (and to a large extent still does).

questions.content: The Antonescu regime was responsible for the crimes committed during the Holocaust in Romania.
questions.explanation: I am not an expert, but it seems quite clear that the historical evidence is overwhelming in this direction.

questions.content: Romania planned militarily and attacked the area around the Hungarian capital, Budapest, after World War I.
questions.explanation: Once again, I am not an expert, but as far as I remember, it was not so much a planned attack, but rather an improvised one triggered by the political developments within Hungary.

questions.content: Due to the different historical contexts in which they developed, Romanian and Moldovan are two related but different languages.
questions.explanation: Only if one defines 'language' in an extremely restrictive manner, closer to a dialect. I don't think that any linguist does it.

questions.content: During the Middle Ages, Transylvania was integrated into Latin Europe, unlike Wallachia and Moldavia, which belonged to the Slavic-Byzantine world.
questions.explanation: Although there are some traces of Slavo-Byzantine culture in medieval Transylvania, the region was undoubtedly part of Latin Europe.

questions.content: The medieval states of Moldavia and Wallachia were formed by breaking away from the Kingdom of Hungary.
questions.explanation: The evidence fully endorses such an interpretation.
